subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Milligan poems
msgSnippet: I can t tell if you re being serious or not. :) In any case that was more or less what I was suggesting. And that s also how I guestimated the 5% and 95%
messageBody:
I can't tell if you're being serious or not. :)

In any case that was more or less what I was suggesting.
And that's also how I guestimated the 5% and 95% figures.
5% of the time would be translating the word list and applying it to the
text.
The other 95% of the job would be proof reading to catch the mistakes.

Thanks for the poem, I've stashed a copy of it away. :)
I pre-emptively took the advice of the last line years ago I'm afraid.

Also, on re-reading my e-mail, it looks like I'm saying I have a word
list with Latin and QuikScript equivalents.
The word list is just the 2940 words in Latin I'm afraid, I never got
any further.

John Cowan wrote:
>
> amd64_hacker scripsit:
>
> > But I still have a list of every word in the text on my hard drive (2940
> > in total, including zik, zizzy and zuzzy).
>
> Better yet, why bother with translating books at all? Just take a wordlist
> sorted in order of frequency, and translate down it until you get
> sick of the job. Then translating books is easy.
>
> (You'll have to special-case heteronyms like _row_ and _desert_.)
>
> A nice little demo for spelling reform is the poem "English is
> Tough Stuff" at http://www.jokes2go.com/poems/7237.html
> <http://www.jokes2go.com/poems/7237.html> .
>
> --
> John Cowan cowan@... <mailto:cowan%40ccil.org>
> "Mr. Lane, if you ever wish anything that I can do, all you will have
> to do will be to send me a telegram asking and it will be done."
> "Mr. Hearst, if you ever get a telegram from me asking you to do
> anything, you can put the telegram down as a forgery."
>
>
